I did some back-of-the-napkin delta-V experiments today for a hypothetical, very large (by my standards, anyway) Jool tug and arrived at the following numbers.  Assuming 8 LV-Ns for engines (I expect some TWR...) and the "ideal" amount of fuel, the rest of the spaceship plus payload came out to the following figures:

200 tons -> 4575m/s

150 tons -> 5387m/s

125 tons -> 5918m/s

100 tons -> 6571m/s

Remember, that tonnage is systems and payload, not just payload.

Assuming a Hohmann transfer to Jool with a Tylo encounter to capture followed by a Hohmann transfer to Kerbin without payload and with a braking burn in LKO (no, I will not subject my spacecraft to aerocapture, thank you very much), what do you think is a reasonable fuel figure?  I figure the rest of the spacecraft systems will probably come to 25~30 tons, maybe a bit more, so the rest is mostly payload and will be ditched in Jool orbit.  Figure 2000m/s to Jool plus another 100~200m/s for Tylo encounter and adjustments, plus another 3000m/s for Jool to Kerbin with braking?

I feel like 5.9km/s (125 tons) would be enough for safety?  Maybe scrape by with 5.3km/s (150 tons) since we're ditching the payload?  I don't know, I always end up spending more than I think doing these sorts of things...  Mind chiming in?
I always take 20% more on interplanetary journeys than Transfer Window Planner says I need.  Like you, no matter how perfect I get it, I always run shorter than the estimate for some reason.
